danish_publication: Der var en kræmmer eller Hamborger-Jøde, der gik på egnen, og han blev slagen ihjel. Det var her i Obbestrup, Gunderup sogn, det passeret, og kræmmeren han vilde til Növling. Der får han en karl til at følge med sig og vise ham vej, og så slog karlen ham ihjel og berövede ham, hvad han havde. Inden han fik ham af med livet, så kom der syv grågjæs flyvende. Så siger Jøden: "De skal være mit vidne til, at du slår mig ihjel." Karlen römte så hans vej og var bort i 20 år, kom derefter til den samme gård, hvor han havde tjent, men de kjendte ham ikke. Da var han jo bleven en svær rig hestepranger, og det var om hösten, han kom der. De forlangede ham til at høste med dem, og det gjorde han også. Så höstede de på det sted, hvor han havde begravet Jøden. Da kommer deher 7 grågjæs öster fra og trækker til vest, og så siger konen: "Gudbevares, grågjæssene kommer så tidlig, a er bange for, de skal æde havren." Men der var en gasse iblandt, og han siger til prangeren: "Der, som du går, der har du slået St.-Peder ihjel." Så bekjendte prangeren med det samme, og han blev rettet på den plads, som han havde begravet den anden, og han blev også kast i jorden på samme plads. På det sted groede ingen ting, det kunde være det samme, hvad de såede, der vilde ingen ting gro. Det er en øde plads kanske den dag i dag er.
english_publication: There was a peddler or a Hamburg-Jew, who walked about the area and he was killed. It was here in Obbestrup, Gunderup parish that it happened and the peddler was on his way to Nøvling. The peddler gets a farmhand to come along with him from there to show him the way, and then the farmhand kills him and robbed him of what he had. Before the farmhand killed the Jew, seven gray geese flew by. Then the Jew says: “They’ll be my witness, that you killed me.” The farmhand then ran away and was gone for twenty years. Then he came back to the same farm where he'd worked, but they didn’t recognize him. At that point he had become a really rich horse trader and it was at harvest time that he arrived. They asked him to help them harvest and he did. Then they harvested on the place where he had buried the Jew. Then these seven gray geese come from the east and go towards the west and then the wife says, “God save us, the gray geese are coming too early, I’m afraid they’ll eat the oats.” But there was a gander among them and he says to the horse dealer: “There where you’re walking, that’s where you killed St. Peder.” Then the horse dealer admitted it on the spot and he was executed on the spot where he had earlier buried the other one, and he was also thrown into the ground in the same place. Nothing grew on that place, it didn’t matter what they planted, nothing would grow there. It’s still a barren place to this day.
